ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Thoughts and tips applying NEAT to OpenAI's Environments
ygData.msgSnippet: Hello Stefano, Thanks very much for the very informative update. OpenAI’s gym is very interesting and it is nice to hear about people’s experience with it.

Subject: Re: [neat] Thoughts and tips applying NEAT to OpenAI's Environments
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=464818732; y=8dEYWLdNBh7xvlPbkYNac-C8zvjaA_52X8k1GhLuLdlY_zcHlN0i

--Apple-Mail=_07D8E7D0-7EC7-45C6-BA62-749EFA9E6E07
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=utf-8

Hello Stefano,

Thanks very much for the very informative update. OpenAI=E2=
=80=99s gym is very interesting and it is nice to hear about people=E2=80=
=99s experience with it. It would be fascinating to see a comparison betwee=
n evolutionary and DeepRL methods on these domains. It sounds like your sen=
se is that NEAT and HyperNEAT are not competitive with DeepRL methods, is t=
hat right?

I am glad you learned something from my paper. In case it is he=
lpful, I just wanted to let you (and anyone else interested) know that we h=
ad a much more extensive journal article that delved more comprehensively i=
nto the issues raised in the conference paper you linked to.That paper is:
=
Clune J, Stanley KO, Pennock RT, Ofria C (2011) On the performance of indir=
ect encoding across the continuum of regularity <http://www.evolvingai.org/=
clune-stanley-pennock-ofria-2011-performance-indirect-encoding> IEEE Transa=
ctions on Evolutionary Computation. 15(3): 346-367. (pdf <http://www.evolvi=
ngai.org/files/2011-CluneEtAl-IndirectEncodingAcrossRegularityContinuum-IEE=
E-TEC.pdf>)
Please keep us posted as you get new results in the gym!

Best =
regards,
Jeff Clune

Loy and Edith Harris Assistant Professor in Computer S=
cience
Director, Evolving Artificial Intelligence Lab <http://evolvingai.or=
g/>
University of Wyoming
jeffclune@... <mailto:jeffclune@...>
je=
ffclune.com <http://jeffclune.com/>
> On Jan 28, 2017, at 5:38 PM, stefano.=
r.palmieri@... [neat] <neat@yahoogroups.com> wrote:
> 
> So I've done=
 quite a few experiments using OpenAI's gym and here are some of my thought=
s about it.
> 
> First off, I really like how OpenAI has made it easy for p=
eople to collaborate and share code and ensuring that researchers are bench=
marking each other on the exact same problems.
> 
> Furthermore, OpenAI's p=
latform is great for beginners to neuroevolution for learning about basic N=
EAT on simple domains such as pole-balancing, lunar-lander or bipedal walke=
rs. However, I don't think that most of OpenAI's environments are adequate =
for neuroevolution research.
> 
> The reason for this is that many of the e=
nvironments are irregular. Unfortunately, it's the simpler environments tha=
t tend to be irregular. So far the environments that I've attempted are=C2=
=A0cartpole-v0, <https://gym.openai.com/envs/CartPole-v0>cartpole-v1, acrob=
ot-v1, mountainCar-v0, MountainCarContinous-v0, pendulum-v0, LunarLander-v2=
, LunarLanderContinuous-v2, BipedalWalker-v2, and BipedalWalkerHardcore-v2.=

> 
> The "classic control" problems are almost too simple for advancing re=
search nor are they good for testing indirect encodings. The reason these e=
nvironments are unsuitable for testing indirect encoding is because the sen=
sors are arranged irregularly (see http://ofria.com/pubs/2008CluneEtAl.pdf)=
. <http://ofria.com/pubs/2008CluneEtAl.pdf> The bipedal walker experiments =
have a small amount of regularity but I believe are still mostly irregular.=
 For some reason before I read Dr. Clune's paper I was under the admittedly=
 silly impression that HyperNEAT would always perform at least as well as N=
EAT. Of course this couldn't be true because of the NFL theorem.
> 
> I hav=
en't tried the Atari, Doom, Minecraft, MuJoCo, and PLE environments yet. I =
believe these may be more regular but they obviously require much more comp=
utational power. I only have a 2014 Macbook Pro so I've been hesitant on at=
tempting these environments.
> 
> Just a heads up for others who may be cur=
ious about using OpenAI Gym. 
> 
>  
> 
> 


--Apple-Mail=_07D8E7D0-7EC7-45C6-BA62-749EFA9E6E07

Content-Type: text/html;
	charset=utf-8

tpole-v0,</span></a>cartpole-v1, acrobot-v1, mountainCar-v0, MountainCarCon=
tinous-v0, pendulum-v0, LunarLander-v2, LunarLanderContinuous-v2, BipedalWa=
lker-v2, and BipedalWalkerHardcore-v2.<br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em;" cl=

or testing indirect encodings. The reason these environments are unsuitable=

/span>The bipedal walker experiments have a small amount of regularity but =
I believe are still mostly irregular. For some reason before I read Dr. Clu=
ne's paper I was under the admittedly silly impression that HyperNEAT would=
 always perform at least as well as NEAT. Of course this couldn't be true b=
ecause of the NFL theorem.<br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em;" class=3D""><br=
 style=3D"line-height: 1.22em;" class=3D"">I haven't tried the Atari, Doom,=
 Minecraft, MuJoCo, and PLE environments yet. I believe these may be more r=
egular but they obviously require much more computational power. I only hav=
e a 2014 Macbook Pro so I've been hesitant on attempting these environments=
.<br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em;" class=3D""><br style=3D"line-height: 1.=
22em;" class=3D"">Just a heads up for others who may be curious about using=
 OpenAI Gym.<span class=3D"Apple-converted-space"> </span><br style=3D=
"line-height: 1.22em;" class=3D""></p><div style=3D"line-height: 1.22em; ma=
